The Fifth Category: That which expresses the tongue of the state (Lisan al-Hal) through the tongue of speech (Lisan al-Maqal). The deficient in understanding stops at the apparent and believes it to be literal speech, while the insightful into realities perceives the secret within it. This is like the saying of the speaker: 'The wall said to the peg: Why do you split me? It said: Ask the one who hammers me, for he did not leave behind me the stone that is behind me.' This is an expression of the tongue of the state (Lisan al-Hal) through the tongue of speech (Lisan al-Maqal). And from this is His saying, the Exalted: 'Then He directed Himself to the heaven while it was smoke and said to it and to the earth: Come both of you willingly or unwillingly. They said: We come willingly.' {} So the dull requires in his understanding to imagine for them life, intellect, and comprehension of the address, and an address that is sound and letter which the heaven and earth hear, then they respond with letter and sound and say: We come willingly. But the insightful knows that this is the tongue of the state (Lisan al-Hal) and that it is a declaration of their being compelled by necessity and forced into subjugation.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Foundations of Belief
The Eighth Foundation: Knowledge that He (Exalted is He) is established upon His Throne with the meaning that Allah (Exalted is He) intended by 'istawa' (establishment), which is that which does not contradict the attribute of Majesty (al-Kibriya) nor is it subject to marks of origination (al-Huduth) and annihilation (al-Fana). And this is what is intended by 'istawa' (He established Himself) towards the heaven, where He said in the Quran: 'Then He established Himself (istawa) towards the heaven while it was smoke' (Quran 41:11). And that is only by way of domination (al-Qahr) and mastery (al-Istila), as the poet said: 'Bishr has established himself over Iraq without sword or spilled blood.' And the people of truth (Ahl al-Haqq) were compelled to this interpretation (ta'wil), just as the people of esotericism (Ahl al-Batin) were compelled to interpret His saying (Exalted is He): 'And He is with you wherever you are' (Quran 57:4), since that was unanimously understood as encompassing (al-Ihata) and knowledge (al-'Ilm). And they interpreted His saying (peace be upon him): 'The heart (Qalb) of the believer is between two fingers of the fingers of the Most Merciful' as power (al-Qudra) and strength (al-Quwwa). And they interpreted His saying (peace be upon him): 'The Black Stone is the right hand (Yamin) of Allah in His earth' as honor (al-Tashrif) and respect (al-Ikram). Because if it were taken according to its apparent meaning, impossibility (al-Muhal) would necessarily follow from it. Likewise, if 'istawa' (establishment) were taken according to settling (al-Istiqrar) and taking position (al-Tamakkun), it would necessarily follow that the one taking position is a body (Jism) in contact with the Throne, either equal to it, larger than it, or smaller than it, and that is impossible (Muhal). And whatever leads to impossibility is impossible.

The second: Pride in physical strength and power, as narrated about the people of 'Ad when they said, as Allah informed about them: "Who is mightier than us in strength?" And as 'Uj relied on his strength and became proud of it, so he uprooted a mountain to crush the army of Musa (peace be upon him), but Allah pierced that piece of the mountain with the pecking of a weak-beaked hoopoe until it became around his neck. And the believer may also rely on his strength, as narrated about Sulayman (peace be upon him) that he said: 'I will go around tonight to one hundred women!' and he did not say 'if Allah wills,' so he was deprived of the offspring he desired. Likewise, the saying of Dawud (peace be upon him): 'If You test me, I will be patient,' and it was pride from him in strength, so when he was tested with the woman, he was not patient. And pride in strength begets rushing into battles, throwing oneself into destruction, and hastening to strike and kill everyone who intends harm to him. Its remedy is what we mentioned, which is to know that there will come a day when his strength weakens! And that if he becomes proud of it, perhaps Allah will strip it from him with the slightest affliction He sends upon him.

And for guidance (Hidayah) there are three stations: The first is knowledge of the path of good and evil, indicated by His saying, the Exalted: 'And We have shown him the two ways (of good and evil)' (Quran 90:10). And Allah, the Exalted, has bestowed this upon all His servants, some of it through the intellect (Aql) and some of it upon the tongue of the messengers. And therefore He, the Exalted, said: 'And as for Thamud, We guided them, but they preferred blindness over guidance' (Quran 41:17). So the means of guidance are the Book and the messengers and the insights of the intellects, and they are made available, and nothing prevents from them except envy (Hasad) and arrogance (Kibr) and love of the worldly life (Dunya) and the causes that blind the hearts (Qulub), even though they do not blind the eyesights. He, the Exalted, said: 'For indeed, it is not the eyes that are blinded, but blinded are the hearts which are within the breasts' (Quran 22:46). And among the blinding things are familiarity (Ilf) and habit (Adah) and the love of adhering to them, and from it is the expression by His saying, the Exalted: 'Indeed, we found our fathers upon a religion' (Quran 43:23) the verse. And from arrogance and envy is the expression by His saying, the Exalted: 'And they said, "Why was this Quran not sent down upon a great man from [one of] the two cities?"' (Quran 43:31) and His saying, the Exalted: 'Shall we follow a human being from among ourselves?' (Quran 54:24). So these blinding things are what prevented the attainment of guidance.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Etiquette of Quran Recitation
Praise be to Allah who bestowed favor upon His servants with His sent Prophet (peace be upon him) and His revealed Book which falsehood does not approach from before it nor from behind it, a revelation from the All-Wise, the Praiseworthy, until it expanded for the people of thoughts the path of consideration with what is in it of stories and reports, and became clear through it the traversing of the straight path and the upright way with what He detailed in it of rulings and distinguished between the lawful and the forbidden. It is the illumination and the light, and through it is salvation from delusion, and in it is healing for what is in the chests. And whoever opposes it from the tyrants, Allah breaks him, and whoever seeks knowledge in other than it, Allah misguides him. It is the firm rope of Allah and His clear light, and the trustworthy handhold and the most faithful refuge, and it encompasses the little and the much, the small and the great. Its wonders do not cease, and its marvels do not end. Its benefits cannot be encompassed by the people of knowledge with limitation, nor does it become worn out for the people of recitation with much repetition. It is the one that guided the first and the last. And when the jinn heard it, they did not delay but turned to their people as warners, and they said: 'Indeed, we have heard an amazing Qur'an that guides to right conduct, so we have believed in it, and we will never associate with our Lord anyone.' So everyone who believes in it has been granted success, and whoever speaks by it has spoken truthfully, and whoever holds fast to it has been guided, and whoever acts by it has attained success. And Allah the Exalted said: "And if We give him a mercy (Rahmah) from Us after hardship (Darra') has touched him, he will surely say, 'This is due to me, and I do not think the Hour (As-Sa'ah) will occur; but if I am returned to my Lord (Rabb), indeed, for me there will be with Him the best (Al-Husna).'" And all of this is from delusion (Ghurur) with Allah. And its cause is a syllogism (Qiyas) from the syllogisms of Iblis (Satan) - we seek refuge in Allah from him - and that is that they look sometimes at the blessings (Ni'am) of Allah upon them in this world (Ad-Dunya) and analogize (Yaqisun) upon them the blessing (Ni'mah) of the Hereafter (Al-Akhirah), and they look sometimes at the delay (Ta'khir) of punishment (Adhab) from them and analogize upon it the punishment (Adhab) of the Hereafter (Al-Akhirah) as Allah the Exalted said: "And they say within themselves, 'Why does Allah not punish us for what we say?'" So Allah the Exalted said in response to their saying: "Sufficient for them is Hell (Jahannam), which they will [enter to] burn, and wretched is the destination (Al-Masir)." And sometimes they look at the believers (Al-Mu'minun); and they are poor (Fuqara'), disheveled (Shu'ath), dusty (Ghubar), so they disdain (Yazdarun) them and belittle (Yastahqirun) them, and they say: "Are these whom Allah has favored among us?" And they say: "If it were [any] good, they would not have preceded us to it." And the arrangement (Tartib) of the syllogism (Al-Qiyas) that He organized (Nazzamahu) in their hearts (Qulub) is that they say: Allah has done good (Ahsana) to us with the enjoyment (Na'im) of this world (Ad-Dunya), and every doer of good (Muhsin) is a lover (Muhibb), and every lover (Muhibb) then he does good (Yuhsinu) also in the future (Al-Mustaqbal) as the poet said: "Indeed Allah has done good (Ahsana) in what has passed, likewise He does good (Yuhsinu) in what remains." And indeed he analogizes (Yaqis) the future (Al-Mustaqbal) upon the past (Al-Madi) by means of honor (Al-Karamah) and love (Al-Hubb) when he says: Were it not that I am honorable (Karim) with Allah and beloved (Mahbub), He would not have done good (Ahsana) to me. And the deception (At-Talbis) is under his assumption (Zann) that every doer of good (Muhsin) is a lover (Muhibb), no, rather under his assumption (Zann) that His bestowing favor (In'am) upon him in this world (Ad-Dunya) is doing good (Ihsan), so he has been deluded (Ightarra) with Allah when he assumed (Zanna) that he is honorable (Karim) with Him by evidence (Dalil) that does not indicate (Yadullu) honor (Al-Karamah) except with the possessors of insight (Dhawu Al-Basa'ir).

And those who reach this rank are divided into the strong ones whose first knowledge is of Allah the Exalted, then through Him they know others.
